How to construct that left adjoint?

From a semi-simplicial set XXX we construct a simplicial set X~\tilde XX~ that's obtained by "freely adding degeneracies".

First let X~0=X0\tilde X_0 = X_0X~0​=X0​. For n=1n = 1n=1, let X1⊆X~1X_1\subseteq \tilde X_1X1​⊆X~1​, also for each x∈X~0x\in \tilde X_0x∈X~0​ and 0≤i≤10\leq i \leq 10≤i≤1 there is an element si(x)∈X~1s_i(x) \in\tilde X_1si​(x)∈X~1​ to serve as the i-th degeneracy. Now we proceed inductively: we let Xn+1⊆X~n+1X_{n+1}\subseteq \tilde X_{n+1}Xn+1​⊆X~n+1​, also for each x∈X~nx\in \tilde X_nx∈X~n​ and 0≤i≤n+10\leq i \leq n+10≤i≤n+1 there is an element si(x)∈X~n+1s_i(x) \in\tilde X_{n+1}si​(x)∈X~n+1​.

To make X~\tilde XX~ a genuine simplicial set, you have to quotient the sets X~n\tilde X_nX~n​ by the simplicial identities. E.g. we freely added the (at this point different) elements τ=s2∘s3(x)\tau = s_2\circ s_3(x)τ=s2​∘s3​(x) and σ=s4∘s2(x)\sigma = s_4\circ s_2(x)σ=s4​∘s2​(x), so we identify τ=σ\tau = \sigmaτ=σ.

I think this is right. Anyway, at nLab [[semi-simplicial set]] there is an abstract construction of both left and right adjoints for the forgetful functor you mention. Also, for any simplicial set XXX, the left unitor gives a weak htpy equivalence to the image of a semi-simplicial set through this adjunction.
You may also enjoy this proposition at Kerodon, and a corollary from it that says that a simplicial map that is a bijection on non-degenerate simplices is an isomorphism
There's a lot more interesting stuff to say about this situation.

If we want to understand the category of semisimplicial sets relative to the category of simplicial sets via the left adjoint you mentioned, we should answer three questions:

  1. Which simplicial sets lie in the image of this functor?
  2. Which morphisms lie in the image of this functor?
  3. When do two parallel morphisms of semisimplicial sets become equal when we apply this functor?

I think, though I haven't carefully checked, that the answers are:

  1. The simplicial sets in which every face of a nondegenerate simplex is nondegenerate.
  2. The morphisms which send nondegenerate simplices to nondegenerate simplices.
  3. Only if the maps were already equal, i.e., the functor is faithful.

There's also a more efficient way to describe what this left adjoint produces, related to the kerodon proposition that Daniel linked to, and using the notion of a "degeneracy operation". A degeneracy operation is an operation taking nnn-simplices to mmm-simplices for some fixed nnn and mmm, for which the corresponding map [m]→[n][m] \to [n][m]→[n] of Δ\DeltaΔ is surjective. (So in particular, n≤mn \le mn≤m.) The operations sis_isi​ are the generating degeneracy operations, and the degeneracy options are all compositions of the sis_isi​, but quotiented by the simplicial relations involving the sis_isi​.

The linked proposition says that every simplex of a simplicial set can be expressed as a degeneracy operation applied to a nondegenerate simplex in a unique way.

Now if we start with a semisimplicial set XXX, we can describe the "free" simplicial set YYY it generates as follows:

  • The simplices of YYY are formal applications of a degeneracy operation to a simplex of XXX.
  • The structure maps of XXX are computed as follows. Suppose we want to compute the action of a simplicial operator fff on a formal degeneracy sxsxsx. The combined operation fsfsfs corresponds to some map of Δ\DeltaΔ which we can refactor as a surjection followed by an injection. Then f(sx)f(sx)f(sx) is given by formally applying the degeneracy operator corresponding to the surjection to the value of the face operator corresponding to the injection on xxx (computed in the semisimplicial set XXX).

A more syntactic way to describe the action in terms of the generating face and degenerating operators is:

  • If we want to apply sis_isi​ to a formal degeneracy sxsxsx, we just form (sis)x(s_i s) x(si​s)x.
  • If we want to apply did_idi​ to a formal degeneracy sxsxsx, then we use the simplicial identities to rewrite disd_i sdi​s as a composition s′d′s' d's′d′ by "moving ds to the left". Since we started with a single did_idi​, what will happen is that either did_idi​ will pass through all the ss (possibly changing indices in the process) so that d=djd = d_jd=dj​, or the did_idi​ will cancel with some s, so that d=idd = \mathrm{id}d=id. Then we compute x′=d′xx' = d' xx′=d′x in XXX and form s′x′s' x's′x′.

Finally, there is also a way to specify an arbitrary simplicial set in terms of only its nondegenerate simplices and its face maps, but with the caveat that the face of a nondegenerate simplex can be a formal degeneracy of another nondegenerate simplex. The full simplicial structure is recovered by the same process as above except that when we take the face of a nondegenerate simplex (in what would have been XXX above), it may come as a formal degeneracy to which we have to apply another degeneracy operator to--which is no problem.

The other caveat is that because of the original question 2, in order to recover the correct maps of simplicial sets, we also need to allow a map to send a nondegenerate simplex to a formal degeneracy in the target simplicial set.
The program Kenzo uses this representation of simplicial sets.

John Baez said:

You can impose any set of equations you want between simplices in a simplicial set, as long as you also impose all the equations that follow via the simplicial identities. You'll get a new simplicial set this way, which will be a quotient of the original one.

What do you mean by that? What confuses me is that when quotienting a simplicial set by an internal equivalence relation the simplicial identities aren't involved at all. (I think one rather has to check that the face and degeneracy maps preserve the relation one wants to quotient by.)

Leopold Schlicht said:

John Baez said:

You can impose any set of equations you want between simplices in a simplicial set, as long as you also impose all the equations that follow via the simplicial identities.

(I think one rather has to check that the face and degeneracy maps preserve the relation one wants to quotient by.)

These seem like two different ways of saying the same thing
To me not. In my way of saying it the simplicial identities aren't involved.
If your relation is already compatible with face/degeneracy maps, then you don't have to "also" impose any relations that follow from their action (because they are already in the original relation)

Of course that's correct, Reid. And on the other hand, you can mod out by imposing any equations you like, without "checking" any properties of these equations, as long as you also impose all equations that follow from these using the definition of simplicial set.

To take a similar example, I can take a group containing two elements xxx and yyy and impose the equation x=yx = yx=y, and also all equations that follow from this via the definition of group (like xz=yzxz = yzxz=yz, etc.), and I'll get a new group, which is a quotient of the original one.

It works like this for any algebraic gadget defined by equations, including multisorted gadgets like simplicial sets. I could state this more formally, but it's easy enough to see it's true.
I didn't say it quite correctly when I said "follow via the simplicial identities" - I should have said "follow via the definition of simplicial set".
So, if we identify two simplexes (of the same dimension), we have to also identify their corresponding faces, and their corresponding degeneracies.
I found out that the adjunction discussed in this thread is often used implicitly in Kerodon, so thanks again for all the answers.
